newsitem.title: UK: Russian debt prices buoyed by IMF agreement.
newsitem.headline: Russian debt prices buoyed by IMF agreement.

text.p: Russian debt prices climbed on Thursday after the International Monetary Fund (IMF) approved the release of delayed money for Russia and bargain-hunting set in following recent weakness, traders said.
Russian MinFins were under pressure on Wednesday after market rumours - swiftly denied - of defaults.
"There has been some bargain hunting in the MinFins and Vnesh after their weakness," said one trader.
Jerome Booth, ANZ Grindlays head of emerging markets research, said the IMF loan disbursement and Russia's negative inflation in August were key price supports.
"In addition to the IMF disbursment, inflation in the week to August 19 was negative, that is very impressive," said Booth.
Russian consumer prices fell 0.1 percent in the week to August 19.
Russian MinFin3 on Thursday were trading up at 75.500/76.500 while MinFin4 were up 0.250 at 48.125/48.625. Dollar-denominated Vnesh paper was up 0.250 at 59.875/60.250.

Traders said bargain hunting on Thursday and support from the IMF approval helped boost prices. The IMF on Wednesday released the July tranche of a $10.2 billion loan which had been frozen because of poor tax collection.
In other debt markets, prices were mostly steady on Thursday as investors waited for the New York market's opening for further direction.
Latin American paper continued to be underpinned by strong economic figures, analysts said.
"We remain very bullish on Mexico Pars. It is only a matter of time until the market goes up. We have to wait for US retail investors to come back from their holidays," added Booth.
Mexican Pars were trading at 67.375/67.625 on Thursday while Mexican Discs were trading at 80.500/80.875.
Traders said the movement in yields on the U.S. long bond will set the tone for Brady prices this afternoon.
"They (yields) slipped half a point on Wednesday and put pressure on the market in general. If the yield remains unchanged the market should remain flat," said a trader.
